title: 107_s1625
content: The "Children's Health Equity Act of 2001" allows for up to 4 state waivers to increase Medicaid children's enrollment using Title XXI allotments. The definitions in this section include terms such as "child," "child health assistance," "enhanced FMAP," "Federal medical assistance percentage," and "poverty line" as defined in the Social Security Act. The Secretary approves up to 4 waiver applications for states meeting specified requirements to receive payments under subsection (d) of the Act. The requirements include SCHIP income eligibility. The Secretary approves waiver applications for states meeting specified requirements to receive payments under subsection (d) of the Act. The requirements include SCHIP income eligibility with the highest income standard permitted under title XXI of the Social Security Act as of January 1, 2001, no waiting list for children below 200 percent of the poverty line, and statewide benefits for all eligible children. The State does not impose any waiting list for children below 200 percent of the poverty line who are eligible for child health assistance. Additionally, the State must implement at least 4 policies related to coverage of children under titles XIX and XXI of the Social Security Act. The State uses a uniform application form for children eligible for medical assistance, eliminates asset tests, and adopts 12-month continuous enrollment. The State adopts 12-month continuous enrollment for children eligible for medical assistance under title XXI of the Social Security Act, ensuring eligibility is not regularly redetermined more than once a year. The State also implements the same verification and redetermination policies for initial eligibility determinations and reassessments. The State implements 12-month continuous enrollment for children eligible for medical assistance under title XXI of the Social Security Act, using the same verification policies for initial eligibility determinations and redeterminations. Automatic reassessment of eligibility is included in redeterminations. The State outstations enrollment staff at designated facilities for processing applications for benefits under title XXI and XIX of the Social Security Act. Payment is authorized for States with approved waivers, regardless of other provisions of law. The Secretary authorizes payment to States with approved waivers under section 2104 of the Social Security Act for medical assistance for children under title XIX. The Secretary determines total medical assistance expenditures for children in the State for fiscal year 1995, compares it to the previous year, and calculates any increase as a bonus amount. The Secretary calculates the bonus amount for children eligible for medical assistance by determining the difference between the enhanced FMAP and the Federal medical assistance percentage for the State. Children described in this paragraph are those eligible for medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act, including those with family income exceeding the highest eligibility level and who would be considered disabled under the Social Security Act. Children eligible for medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act, including those with family income exceeding the highest eligibility level and who would be considered disabled under the Act, may receive supplemental security income benefits if their earnings or deemed income/resources exceed the requirements. States with approved waivers will receive payments in a specific order under section 2105(a) of the Act. Payments to states under section 2105(a) of the Social Security Act for a fiscal year are prioritized in the following order: (A) expenditures for items in paragraph (1)(A), (B) expenditures for items in paragraph (1)(B), (C) payment authorized under subsection (d)(1), (D) expenditures for items in paragraph (1)(C), and (E) expenditures for items in paragraph (1)(D).
